'''HMS ''Bold''''' was a 14-gun {{sclass|Bold|gun-brig}} built by Tyson & Blake at [[Bursledon]]. She was launched in 1812 and wrecked off Prince Edward's Island on 27 September 1813.
==Design and construction== The ''Bold'' class were a revival of Sir William Rule's {{sclass|Confounder|gun-brig}} design of 1804. They were armed with ten 18-pounder [[carronade]]s and two 6-pounder [[chase gun|bow chasers]]. Built at [[Bursledon]] by Tyson & Blake, ''Bold'' was launched on 26 June 1812 and commissioned in July 1812 under [[s:A Naval Biographical Dictionary/Skekel, John|Commander John Skekel]], who sailed for North America in her on 17 April 1813.<ref name=Winfield/>
==Service== On 18 or 26 May 1813 (records differ), while in the company of the [[City of Halifax|Halifax]] [[privateer]] [[Sir John Sherbrooke (Halifax)|''Sir John Sherbrooke'']], the two vessels recaptured the ''Duck'', which the American privateer ''General Plummer'' had taken shortly before.<ref>Parkinson & Fayle (2006), p. 246.</ref> The ''Duck'' had been traveling from Waterford to Newfoundland.<ref>{{London Gazette|startpage=20|issue=16837|date=1 January 1814}}</ref>
==Fate== On the morning of 27 September 1813, ''Bold'' grounded on the north end of [[Prince Edward's Island]] between 3 and 4am. Some accounts emphasize that this occurred during a strong NE gale.<ref>Marshall (1831), Vol. 3, Part 1, pp.223-5.</ref> However the court martial account does not mention this.<ref name=Hepper>Hepper (1994), p. 148.</ref> Despite efforts to lighten her, ''Bold'' remained stuck and ultimately had to be abandoned. In the morning it was clear that she was a cable-length (i.e., a little more than an eight of a mile) from shore. The crew established a line to the shore through the surf and this enabled a boat to go back and forth between vessel and shore. The result was that her entire crew of 67 officers and men were saved.<ref name=Hepper/>
A small party went overland to [[Charlottetown]] to seek help while the remainder of the crew attempted to salvage what it could. Lieutenant Governor C. D. Smith sent the transport ''Agnes'', which had recently arrived at Charlestown, with ordnance stores for the garrison, to assist ''Bold '' and recover stores.<ref>''Naval Chronicle'', Vol. 30, p.430.</ref><ref group=Note>The ''Naval Chronicle'' gives the name of ''Bold{{'}}''s captain as Sackwell, but this is incorrect.</ref> ''Agnes'' took ''Bold''{{'}}s crew to [[City of Halifax|Halifax]].<ref>''Alexandria Gazette''. Commercial and Political (Alexandria, Virginia), 9 November 1813, p.3.</ref>
The subsequent court martial reprimanded Skekel and the master for having neglected to instruct the watch to take frequent depth soundings. It also fined the local pilot for not having warned Skekel about the currents in the area.<ref name=Hepper/> John Skekel went on to another command and in time became an admiral.
